The 'AKM' (; Avtomat Kalashnikova Modernizirovanniy or "Kalashnikov modernized
automatic rifle") is a 7.62mm assault rifle designed by Mikhail Kalashnikov. It
is an upgraded version of the AK-47 rifle and was developed in the 1950s.

Introduced into service with the Soviet Army in 1959, the AKM is the most
ubiquitous variant of the entire AK series of firearms and it has found
widespread use with most member states of the former Warsaw Pact and its many
African and Asian allies as well as being widely exported and produced in many
other countries. The production of these Soviet rifles was carried out at both
the Tula Arms Plant and Izhmash. It was officially replaced in Soviet Front-Line
service by the AK-74 in the late 1970s, but remains in use worldwide.
categories: Infantry weapons of the Cold War
